page.title: 12COAL MINING
page.content: Pits in and around Barlborough had very odd names such as 'The Fox and Magpie',at Quarry Dam,and 'The Fat and Flour', which got it's name from the fact that it was owned by two gentlemen,namely Mr.Mallinder,the local butcher and Mr.Garfitt,the local baker and was situated in the Barlborough Common area. The village was comparatively prosperous during the 19th century, supplying coal to various local industries. In 1873 Barlborough No.1 colliery,owned by the Staveley Coal and Iron Company,was sunk;it gave employment to 550 people at its peak and it turned out 200,000 tons.
